channel.title: OnOptions
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: What’s the Best Age to Start a Business? It Just Might Be Your 60s
item.description: Entrepreneurship after retirement age? It could be a really good idea.

item.title: These traffic lights use AI to always turn green for cyclists
item.description: If you ride along a bike path in the U.K. city of Leeds and approach a street, the traffic light can automatically turn green for you—or stay green if...

item.title: Upwork CEO Hayden Brown: ‘There will be plenty of work for humans, even as AI agents do more’
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: Why innovation never sleeps at Synchrony
item.description: Synchrony’s CEO, Brian Doubles, shares with Stephanie Mehta how a mindset of “ productive paranoia” fosters a workplace where curiosity, collaboration...

item.title: What happens when C-suite pay becomes all or nothing
item.description: Inside the new era of high-stakes compensation that rewards only those who deliver outsize success.

item.title: Headless browsing is on the rise. Here’s why that could get scary for businesses
item.description: The rise of artificial intelligence in recent years, along with the surge in AI-generated online content, has given more credibility to a decades-old ...

item.title: White House: Mass Layoffs Will Start if Shutdown Talks ‘Going Nowhere’
item.description: The Senate will vote on Monday whether to end the shutdown.

item.title: Neuroscience Says This Is How You Can Turn a Bad Memory Into a Good (and Useful) Memory
item.description: A chemical in your brain assigns a positive or negative emotion to specific situations, and there are definitely ways you can game the system.

item.title: You’ve Heard of Introverts and Extroverts, But Maybe You’re an Otrovert Instead
item.description: Move over introverts and extroverts. Psychiatry has a new term — otrovert — for those who don’t fit neatly into either label.

item.title: How CEOs are thinking about tackling political and social issues in today’s climate
item.description: Headwinds across the business world challenge any leader striving to make an impact beyond shareholder value. Few organizations know this struggle bet...

item.title: Surprise in Japan’s leadership race jolts financial markets as the dollar soars against the yen
item.description: Takaichi favors looser fiscal and monetary policies, raising expectations that Tokyo will issue more debt while the central bank rethinks rate hikes.

item.title: Companies ask candidates for references. Why can’t candidates ask companies for the same?
item.description: Companies ask job applicants for references all the time. It’s a way to verify a potential hire ’s history and skills, vet their candidacy, and assess...

item.title: A Massive New Study of 27,500 People Says This Is How Bad Sleep Habits Can Change Your Brain
item.description: If you’re reading this article late at night on your phone, maybe make it the last one of the evening.

item.title: Gold and Bitcoin go through the roof as U.S. shutdown forces investors to trade in the dark
